Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, my hands gripping the steering wheel tighter than usual. The medical supply box in the backseat was marked “URGENT—HOSPITAL DELIVERY.” I knew the hospital was counting on me to get it there on time; a delay could mean real trouble for patients. But as I turned onto Main Street, my mind kept drifting to my wallet, sitting on my kitchen counter at home. Today was the only morning I could swing by and grab my ID before work, and I needed it to vote. The polls would be open tomorrow, but my shift was packed—no chance to get home then. My supervisor had drilled it into us: no late deliveries, especially not to the hospital. But I also felt the weight of my civic duty, the expectation that I’d show up prepared and cast my ballot. My heart pounded as I neared the intersection—one way led to the hospital, the other to my apartment. I could feel the pressure from both sides, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
